docs.snippet: It doesn't hurt to be known as the Google of Russia.     Shares of Yandex, the Russian search engine company, shot up more than 55 percent in their Nasdaq market debut last week. The stock's rise illustrates investors' voracious appetite for emerg...
docs.lead_paragraph: It doesn't hurt to be known as the Google of Russia. Shares of Yandex, the Russian search engine company, shot up more than 55 percent in their Nasdaq market debut last week. The stock's rise illustrates investors' voracious appetite for emerging-market investments and Internet initial public offerings. But Yandex is also a sign of another trend: investors are willing to ignore the special risks associated with foreign Internet companies in their hunger for riches.

headline.main: In Hunger for Foreign Tech Stocks, Investors See the Riches, Not the Risks

docs.abstract: Steven M Davidoff Deal Professor column contends that rapid surge in share price for Yandex, Russian search engine company, illustrates voracious appetite among investors for emerging-market tech investments, and willingness to ignore special risks associated with foreign Internet companies; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Oregon soon could become the second state to allow peer-to-peer car sharing. Legislation establishing standards for personal vehicle sharing programs was approved this week by the House of Representatives and the Senate. HB 3149 paves the way for residents to rent their cars directly to other people through vehicle sharing programs like Getaround or the Google-backed RelayRides. California passed a similar law last year.

headline.main: Peer-to-Peer Car Sharing Gains Traction in Oregon

One click will take you to a news site, and you can choose which language you would like to read it in, thanks to Google’s translation services. The site is the work of Great Name, a Web-development squad from Gothenburg, Sweden (home of both Metro and Götesborgs Posten).

docs.snippet: Q.Is it true you can get a virus from Google Images?     A.Security researchers have found thousands of photos from searches within the Google Images site that have been infected with malicious code. In many cases, clicking on one of these poisone...
docs.lead_paragraph: Q.Is it true you can get a virus from Google Images? A.Security researchers have found thousands of photos from searches within the Google Images site that have been infected with malicious code. In many cases, clicking on one of these poisoned images triggers a script that makes it seem like the computer has become infected with viruses. Another Web site pops up trying to wheedle your credit-card number in exchange for fake antivirus software.

headline.main: Poisoned Pictures on the Web

docs.abstract: Personal Tech Q&A on printing properly in Internet Explorer 9 (S)

docs.snippet: Q.Ever since I upgraded to Internet Explorer 9, I have been having trouble printing Web pages, which come out looking different than what's on screen. What's wrong?A.To speed up its handling of Web pages, Internet Explorer 9 shifts the workload fr...
docs.lead_paragraph: Q.Ever since I upgraded to Internet Explorer 9, I have been having trouble printing Web pages, which come out looking different than what's on screen. What's wrong?A.To speed up its handling of Web pages, Internet Explorer 9 shifts the workload from the computer's main processor to the graphics processor. If your computer's video card does not support this type of hardware acceleration, your Web pages may print incorrectly. Update your printer's driver software to make sure outdated software is not the culprit. You can download the latest files for your printer model from the Support area of the manufacturer's Web site.

headline.main: Printing Properly In Internet Explorer 9

docs.abstract: Personal Tech Q&A on photos from Google Images site that have been infected with malicious code (S)

docs.snippet: As the new pitching coach for the Brooklyn Cyclones, the Mets' rookie-level team in the New York-Penn League, Frank Viola will have few pupils who were born in the 1980s, when he starred for the Minnesota Twins. But his pitchers will discover who ...
docs.lead_paragraph: As the new pitching coach for the Brooklyn Cyclones, the Mets' rookie-level team in the New York-Penn League, Frank Viola will have few pupils who were born in the 1980s, when he starred for the Minnesota Twins. But his pitchers will discover who he is. ''A lot of the kids have to Google you to see what your career was,'' Viola said last week. ''Once they realize what you did, you've got their respect and they're into you. But then if you can't help them along the way, it doesn't matter what you've done. So there's a fine line between using it to your advantage and losing the kid because you're talking about it too much. So hopefully, I'm doing it the right way.''

headline.main: Viola Renews Tie to Mets

docs.abstract: Extra Bases column; Frank Viola, former MLB standout with Minnesota Twins, makes return to professional baseball as pitching coach for the Brooklyn Cyclones, the New York Mets' Class A affiliate of the New York-Penn League. (M)

docs.snippet: The ability of search engines to calculate basic arithmetic right in the search box is well known, but some can handle higher math as well....
docs.lead_paragraph: The ability of search engines to calculate basic arithmetic right in the search box is well known, but some can handle higher math as well. Both Bing and Google can perform trigonometric functions like sine, cosine and tanget when the sin, cos and tan operators are typed into the search box. For example, typing “sin 45 degrees” and hitting the Enter key brings a result of 0.707107 — with no digging around for a calculator. Microsoft has a full list of mathematical operations that work with Bing here; a similar list for Google is here.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Using Search Engines for Higher Math

docs.snippet: Whether you are trying to find the best time to travel to a spot or have no destination in mind, a little-known travel tool, Kayak Explore (kayak.com/explore), can help you find the best flight deals. Explore is bundled with Kayak's online suite, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Whether you are trying to find the best time to travel to a spot or have no destination in mind, a little-known travel tool, Kayak Explore (kayak.com/explore), can help you find the best flight deals. Explore is bundled with Kayak's online suite, which includes flight and hotel search options, and a useful list of airline fees. The concept is simple: enter a departure city and then select a time frame for travel. The results are displayed on a large Google map, with best fares plotted between your city and hundreds of destinations. Results can be filtered by region, price range, flight duration and desired activities (like going to the beach, golfing or skiing). If you adjust the month from August to September, for example, you will see drastic price drops for flights to Europe.

headline.main: A Map That Shows Where to Go, Plus Fares

docs.abstract: In Transit blog; Kayak Explore, which is bundled with Kayak's online suite, offers a map with the best airline fares plotted between a specified city and hundreds of destinations; map (M)

docs.snippet: HopStop is branching away from giving directions for public transportation and turning itself into a more general-use lifestyle app for urban dwellers....
docs.lead_paragraph: When HopStop was founded in 2005, the idea that a user could type two addresses into a Web site and get reliable directions about how to travel between them on public transportation was a pretty unique idea. How times have changed. Today there are over 40 mobile apps focused on New York City’s transportation system alone, and Google gives directions for drivers, walkers and bus and subway riders through its Web site and its mobile app, which comes installed on many smartphones.

headline.main: HopStop to Offer More Than Directions

docs.abstract: HopStop is branching away from giving directions for public transportation and turning itself into a more general-use lifestyle app for urban dwellers.

docs.snippet: The Google Street View car was just asking for trouble — and I was happy to oblige....

headline.seo: Lives - Tailing the Google Street Car
headline.main: Stalking the Stalkers

docs.snippet: On the corner of State and Camp, I came upon a Google Street View car at a stop sign. The driver was a young, husky guy with mirrored shades, a faint goatee and a phone pressed to the side of his head. The car was painted in bright colors with the...
docs.lead_paragraph: On the corner of State and Camp, I came upon a Google Street View car at a stop sign. The driver was a young, husky guy with mirrored shades, a faint goatee and a phone pressed to the side of his head. The car was painted in bright colors with the Google logo, and jutting upward from the roof was a small tower on which sat a bright red ball that contained a camera. It looked like a giant penis with an eye. I was on my Vespa, and I pulled over. The car crossed State Street and headed up Camp, toward Audubon Park. California plates. I took out my iPhone, turned on the camera and pursued. The adrenaline that coursed through me contained a mixture of surprise, excitement and hostility. Cameras are ubiquitous in any city, especially in New Orleans -- there are the parents of little kids,always snapping away; the tourists framing this house, that tree; and the many movie sets, gargantuan operations set up like medieval encampments. Landlords talk excitedly about renting to ''movie people.''

headline.main: Stalking the Stalkers

docs.abstract: Thomas Beller Lives essay describes his attempt to stalk a driver in a Google Street View car; drawing (M)

docs.snippet: The work in question, by a 17th-century Dutch painter, once belonged to an art dealer who was killed at Auschwitz; the painting was likely seized by the Nazis....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston said it would pay an unspecified amount to the heir of an art dealer who was killed at Auschwitz and will keep a 17th-century Dutch painting in its collection that was once owned by the dealer and likely seized by the Nazis. The Boston Globe reported that after a lengthy investigation into the work, an oil portrait by the Dutch painter Eglon van der Neer, the museum determined that it had belonged to Walter Westfeld, who had run a German gallery shut down by the Nazis in 1936 and who was sent to Auschwitz in 1943. The museum, which purchased the painting in 1941, posted an image of it online in 2000 amid concerns about its provenance; in 2004 it was contacted by Fred Westfield, a nephew of the art dealer. Mr. Westfield, a retired economics professor in Tennessee, learned about the painting from a Google search. The Globe said that the museum had in recent years returned other works stolen during World War II. It also fought a legal battle to keep the Oskar Kokoschka painting “Two Nudes (Lovers)”; a federal appeals court ruled last year that it was the rightful owner of this work.

headline.main: Museum of Fine Arts Reaches Restitution Deal to Keep Painting

docs.abstract: The work in question, by a 17th-century Dutch painter, once belonged to an art dealer who was killed at Auschwitz; the painting was likely seized by the Nazis.

docs.snippet: Google quietly unveiled a new Web page, called What Do You Love, that pulls together search results with all the tools and services the company offers. In creating the template, however, Google’s engineers did not realize how funny the results c...
docs.lead_paragraph: Today, Google quietly began a Web page called What Do You Love, or WDYL for short. (You have to type in www before wdyl.com to get the page.) It’s an aggregation of all the Google tools and services, centered around a search you enter on a familiar-looking search-box page. If you wanted to see all the things Google can do with, say, the Yankees, you could enter that word into the box and get a page that looks like this:

headline.main: The Unintended Humor of Google’s New Search Page

docs.abstract: Google quietly unveiled a new Web page, called What Do You Love, that pulls together search results with all the tools and services the company offers. In creating the template, however, Google’s engineers did not realize how funny the results can be.

docs.snippet: The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston said it would pay an unspecified amount to the heir of an art dealer who was killed at Auschwitz and will keep a 17th-century Dutch painting in its collection that was once owned by the dealer and likely seized by...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston said it would pay an unspecified amount to the heir of an art dealer who was killed at Auschwitz and will keep a 17th-century Dutch painting in its collection that was once owned by the dealer and likely seized by the Nazis. The Boston Globe reported that after a lengthy investigation into the work, an oil portrait by the Dutch painter Eglon van der Neer, the museum determined that it had belonged to Walter Westfeld, who had run a German gallery shut down by the Nazis in 1936 and who was sent to Auschwitz in 1943. The museum, which purchased the painting in 1941, posted an image of it online in 2000 amid concerns about its provenance; in 2004 it was contacted by Fred Westfield, a nephew of the art dealer. Mr. Westfield, a retired economics professor in Tennessee, learned about the painting from a Google search. The Globe said that the museum had in recent years returned other works stolen during World War II. It also fought a legal battle to keep the Oskar Kokoschka painting ''Two Nudes (Lovers)''; a federal appeals court ruled last year that it was the rightful owner of this work. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline.main: Museum of Fine Arts Has Deal on Painting

docs.abstract: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, will pay unspecified amount to heir of art dealer who was killed at Aushwitz in order to keep 17th-century Dutch painting that was once owned by dealer and likely seized by Nazis (S)

docs.snippet: The company offering tiny credit card readers for smartphones and tablets got a new round of financing....
docs.lead_paragraph: Evelyn Rusli at Dealbook writes that early on Wednesday, Square, the fast-growing mobile payments start-up, announced the completion of a $100 million financing round, led by Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers, a leading venture capital firm that has backed Google and Amazon. The round values the company at $1.6 billion, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline.main: Dealbook: Unprofitable Square Valued at $1.6 Billion

docs.snippet: Google’s new social-networking site could have an unlikely ally in its corner to convince users to sign up for it....
docs.lead_paragraph: This week, Google slowly began rolling out invitations to its new social network, called Google+. The service is similar to Facebook but aimed at allowing people to share and discuss photos, links and status updates with small pockets of friends, rather than someone’s entire social network.
